articles.headline: Investors in Developing Markets See Optimism
articles.snippet: If investors in New York and London are seeing the green shoots of economic recovery, their counterparts in developing countries are witnessing a full-on spring.
articles.abstract: If investors in New York and London are seeing the green shoots of economic recovery, their counterparts in developing countries are witnessing a full-on spring.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  If investors in New York and London are seeing the first delicate signs of a recovery, their counterparts in developing countries say they are witnessing a full-on spring.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: G.M.’s Chief Promises Full Details of Restructuring
articles.snippet: The chief executive of General Motors, Fritz Henderson, told Congress that “it’s our obligation to be open and transparent in all we do to reinvent G.M.”
articles.abstract: The chief executive of General Motors, Fritz Henderson, told Congress that “it’s our obligation to be open and transparent in all we do to reinvent G.M.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of General Motors, Fritz Henderson, vowed to Congress on Wednesday that as long as the American taxpayer was its largest investor, “it’s our obligation to be open and transparent in all we do to reinvent G.M.”

articles.headline: Taiwan Tech Firms Strive to Be Global
articles.snippet: No longer content in the background, companies from Taiwan are seeking the higher profits of a global brand.
articles.abstract: No longer content in the background, companies from Taiwan are seeking the higher profits of a global brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan  For more than a decade, Western technology companies and Taiwanese manufacturers had a simple, mutually beneficial arrangement.

articles.headline: Regulator to Detail Plan for Derivatives
articles.snippet: The plan by the top futures trading official will impose new restrictions, and higher costs, on those trading in the instruments.
articles.abstract: The plan by the top futures trading official will impose new restrictions, and higher costs, on those trading in the instruments.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The new chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission will ask Congress on Thursday to impose substantial new costs and restrictions on large banks and other financial institutions that deal in the complex and largely unregulated financial instruments known as derivatives.

articles.headline: Tiananmen Square Scars Soldier Turned Artist
articles.snippet: Chen Guang, an artist and a former soldier who helped clear Tiananmen Square in 1989, has defied officials to describe his experiences there.
articles.abstract: Chen Guang, an artist and a former soldier who helped clear Tiananmen Square in 1989, has defied officials to describe his experiences there.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Soaked in sweat, his heart racing, Chen Guang descended the steps of China’s Great Hall of the People and aimed his automatic rifle at the sea of student protesters occupying Tiananmen Square. A 17-year-old soldier from the countryside, Mr. Chen and his comrades had just been given chilling orders: to clear the symbolic heart of the nation, even if it meant spilling blood.

articles.headline: Rise in Oil Price Eases Push for Reform in Russia
articles.snippet: Downturns have produced major reforms in Russia in the past, but last year’s collapse in oil prices may not have lasted long enough to bring about change.
articles.abstract: Downturns have produced major reforms in Russia in the past, but last year’s collapse in oil prices may not have lasted long enough to bring about change.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  Russia’s stock market is up about 80 percent this spring, a bounce that is astonishing even by the standards of recent recoveries in other emerging markets.

articles.headline: Slump Pushing Cost of Drugs Out of Reach
articles.snippet: Even with low-cost generics and discounting by big chains, many Americans still find themselves unable to afford their prescription medications.
articles.abstract: Even with low-cost generics and discounting by big chains, many Americans still find themselves unable to afford their prescription medications.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROCKY MOUNT, N.C.  A year or so ago, when customers buttonholed the pharmacists at Almand’s Drug Store here the questions were invariably about dosing or side effects. These days, they are almost always about cost.

articles.headline: Palm Pre, Elegant Contender
articles.snippet: Palm’s new multitouch smartphone may be the challenger that can finally out-iPhone the iPhone.
articles.abstract: Palm’s new multitouch smartphone may be the challenger that can finally out-iPhone the iPhone.
articles.lead_paragraph: You’ve seen that movie, right? The one where a pair of lovable sad-sack losers team up to defeat the smug athletic golden boy?

articles.headline: Rising Interest on Nations’ Debts May Sap World Growth
articles.snippet: Countries worldwide are paying higher interest rates on their expanding debt, which could translate into hundreds of billions of dollars more in spending.
articles.abstract: Countries worldwide are paying higher interest rates on their expanding debt, which could translate into hundreds of billions of dollars more in spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: As governments worldwide try to spend their way out of recession, many countries are finding themselves in the same situation as embattled consumers: paying higher interest rates on their rapidly expanding debt.

articles.headline: Rival Messages as Obama Lands in the Mideast
articles.snippet: As President Obama continued his Mideast trip, voices as disparate as Al Qaeda’s and the Israeli government’s competed to shape how his message would be heard.
articles.abstract: As President Obama continued his Mideast trip, voices as disparate as Al Qaeda’s and the Israeli government’s competed to shape how his message would be heard.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Aiming to repair the American relationship with the Muslim world, President Obama was greeted on Wednesday with reminders of the vast gulfs his Cairo speech must bridge, as voices as disparate as Al Qaeda’s and the Israeli government’s competed to shape how Mr. Obama’s message would be heard.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Cleared of Terror Charges, Facing Deportation
articles.snippet: Many defendants are brought up on immigration charges after prosecutors fail to win terrorism convictions.
articles.abstract: Many defendants are brought up on immigration charges after prosecutors fail to win terrorism convictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOORE HAVEN, Fla.  Youssef Samir Megahed toyed with a piece of lint on the other side of the bulletproof glass and described his case as simply “weird.”

articles.headline: Balancing Act for Republican on Court Nominee
articles.snippet: Senator John Cornyn personifies the competing pressures Republicans face as they sort through how to handle the nomination of Judge Sonia Sotomayor.
articles.abstract: Senator John Cornyn personifies the competing pressures Republicans face as they sort through how to handle the nomination of Judge Sonia Sotomayor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator John Cornyn, the Texas Republican, was not happy when he heard other Republicans toss around the term “racist” in reference to Judge Sonia Sotomayor, the Supreme Court nominee.

articles.headline: Addressing Muslims, Obama Pushes Mideast Peace
articles.snippet: In a speech in Cairo, President Obama pledged to pursue a two-state solution to Middle East peace “that is in Israel’s interest, Palestine’s interest.”
articles.abstract: In a speech in Cairo, President Obama pledged to pursue a two-state solution to Middle East peace “that is in Israel’s interest, Palestine’s interest.”
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  In opening a bold overture to the Islamic world on Thursday, President Obama confronted frictions between Muslims and the West, but he reserved some of his bluntest words for Israel, as he expressed sympathy for the Palestinians and what he called the “daily humiliations, large and small, that come with occupation.”
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Alan Cowell
